10   Appendix 4   
PROJECT PREPARATORY TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
 
A.  Justification 
 
1.  The Government of Indonesia requested Asian Development Bank (ADB) for support in 
implementing the Forest Investment Program (FIP). A project preparatory technical assistance 
(PPTA) is required to conduct due diligence and prepare relevant documents for compliance 
with requirements of the FIP sub-committee and ADB. Based on meaningful and effective 
engagement of communities and other stakeholders, the PPTA will collect baseline data, assess 
critical issues affecting sustainability of REDD+ implementation, identify target locations, assess 
feasibility of various activities, and develop an agreed project design.   
 
B.  Major Outputs and Activities 
2.  The key output of PPTA will be a feasibility study report in the format of ADB’s Report 
and Recommendation of the President (RRP) and its appendices. The TA will undertake the 
detailed design of the project by performing various activities, including: (i) detailed scoping and 
assessments of the activities listed in concept paper, (ii) assessment of institutional capacity, 
human  resources  development  needs  and  monitoring  mechanisms  for  the  proposed 
interventions,  (iii)  effective  communication  and  meaningful  engagement  with  civil  society 
organizations, national and sub-national governments, private sector and local and indigenous 
communities,  (iv)  baseline  data  collection  for  key  indicators  in  the  design  and  monitoring 
framework, (v) identification of specific areas to direct FIP support and assessment of feasible 
partnership  arrangements,  (vi)  due  diligence  assessments  (technical,  economic,  social 
[involuntary resettlement and indigenous peoples’ impacts], environmental, land tenure risks) for 
project financing and any necessary surveys, consultation and refinement for implementation 
plan, (vii) preparation of sample procurement documentation for both Consultant Recruitment 
and Procurement of Goods and Works, and (viii) preparation of necessary documents for 
approval of grant funding by FIP sub-committee. The TA will prepare reports on poverty and 
social  assessment,  environmental  assessment,  indigenous  peoples  and  land  tenure, 
stakeholder communication strategy, and consultation and participation plan for local community 
engagement to ensure beneficiaries benefit fully from the project’s activities.

C.  Cost Estimate and Proposed Financing Arrangement  
4.  The TA is estimated to cost $500,000 equivalent, to be financed on a grant basis by 
ADB Strategic Climate Fund and administered by ADB.1 The government, through the Ministry 
of Forestry (MoFr), will contribute in the form of counterpart staff remuneration and transport, 
office  supplies,  communication  and  meeting  facilities,  and  other  in-kind  contributions.  The 
detailed cost estimate is presented in Table A4.2.

D.  Consulting Services 
5.  ADB will recruit an international consulting firm using quality- and cost-based selection 
(90:10 to emphasize technical aspects of the assignment) and simplified technical proposal in 
accordance with the ADB’s Guidelines on the Use of Consultants (2013, as amended from time 
to time). The consulting team will conduct a detailed capacity assessment of EA and IAs, and 
suggest a remedial action plan to minimize procurement and financial management risks. Table 
A4.3  shows  the  summary  of  consulting  services  requirement.  The  consulting  firm  will  be 
responsible for  the  administration  of  workshops, training  seminars,  and  surveys  under  the 
PPTA. Equipment and assets purchased under the work will adhere to ADB's Procurement 
Guidelines (March 2013, as amended from time to time), and upon completion of the project, 
the assets will be turned over to the EA.

6.  The team leader and the deputy team leader will coordinate all TA activities and prepare 
a detailed plan for implementation of the project, including consulting services, procurement 
method, and detailed cost estimates. They will be responsible for the delivery and overall quality 
of  the  inception,  interim  and  final  reports.  All  specialists  will  contribute  to  preparation  of 
documents such as draft report and recommendation to the president, related linked documents 
including  a  draft  project  administration  manual,  good  governance  framework,  and  other 
documents necessary for approval by the FIP sub-committee and the ADB Board.  
 
7.  REDD+ communications specialist will develop a project communications strategy that 
identifies key communication channels and approaches to share FIP project information and 
enable consultations and feedback. S/he will assist in planning, coordinating and implementing 
special events promoting communications with diverse stakeholders, and prepare documents in 
Bahasa for effective communication of project design related activities. The indigenous peoples 
and social safeguards specialists will assess impacts on IPs, impacts on natural and cultural 
resources in IP lands, and options for using dedicated grant mechanism for local communities.  
They will develop an Indigenous Peoples framework and/or plan In accordance with ADB’s 
Safeguard Policy Statement and national REDD+ safeguards policies of Indonesia. They will 
also prepare social impact assessment report, determine involuntary resettlement impacts and 
prepare a resettlement framework and/or plan.  
 
8.  Community  development  and  participation  specialist  will  prepare  the  stakeholder 
consultation  and  participation  plan,  and  organize  stakeholder  consultations  and  surveys  to 
identify target locations for FIP support, partnership arrangements, and effective approaches for 
KPH support to communities. The gender specialists will prepare a gender action plan, with 
gender-related performance indicators/targets. They will prepare the due diligence assessment 
on gender impacts, including potential benefits and adverse effects of each project output in the 
project areas for Dayak and trans-migrant women in particular, and provide relevant inputs to 
the PAM. The environment specialist will conduct an initial environmental examination, outline 
appropriate measures and prepare the environmental assessment review framework. The forest 
carbon monitoring, reporting and verification (MRV) specialists will collect spatial and other data 
needed for analyzing drivers of deforestation and establish baseline status of forest carbon in 
target sites and villages. They will prepare a report covering: the business as usual emissions

scenario, reference emissions level for the target area, local capacities for monitoring REDD+, 
and recommendations for REDD+ MRV consistent with the FIP Results Framework.  
 
9.  Spatial information systems specialist will collect data and prepare maps needed for 
analyzing drivers of deforestation. S/he will access spatial data used in the One Map initiative 
and help the PPTA team recommend where carbon stocks can be conserved, protected and/or 
restored through community-focused investments. REDD+ economists will prepare the due 
diligence assessment on economic and financial viability including incentive and transaction 
cost issues, and recommend a fund flow mechanism and other procedures for inclusion in the 
PAM.  The  financial  management  specialist  will  assess  the  capacity  of  executing  and 
implementing agencies in financial management and design project fund flow/disbursement 
mechanisms in accordance with ADB’s Financial Management and Analysis of Projects (2005). 
Procurement specialist will assess procurement capacity of the executing and implementing 
agencies and prepare procurement plan and sample procurement documentation for contracts. 
 
10.  The qualifications and detailed terms of reference for various consultants and the PPTA 
deliverables are given separately in Supplementary Document 4. 
 
E.  Implementation Arrangements 
11.  The  Ministry  of  Forestry  (MoFr)  will  be  the  executing  agency  (EA).  The  Center  for 
Standardization and Environment (Pustanling) of MoFr will be the implementing agency (IA), in 
close  cooperation  with  provincial  and  district  administrations  (including  forest  management 
units). An inter-ministerial FIP steering committee2 will guide the overall program, ensure inter-
ministerial coordination and provide oversight for the PPTA. The director of Pustanling will be 
responsible for coordination and implementation of all activities of the PPTA, including effective 
monitoring of the work progress of consultants in accordance with the implementation schedule 
and plan. Disbursements under the PPTA will follow ADB’s Technical Assistance Disbursement 
Handbook (2013, as amended from time to time). The proposed PPTA commencement date is 
16 June 2014 and the completion date is 15 March 2015 (9 months). 
 
12.  The proposed TA processing and implementation schedule is listed in Table A4.4.

Bappenas, UKP4, and the National Forestry Council (DKN) as members and the three MDBs as observers.
